H0.text: Lymph capillaries collect fluid that leaks out from blood capillaries.

H1.text: Pulmonary capillaries collect fluid that leaks out from blood capillaries.

H2.text: Varicose veins are structures that collect fluid that leaks out from blood capillaries.

H3.text: Alveoli collect fluid that leaks out from blood capillaries.

A4.text: Lymph capillaries are dispersed among the blood-related capillaries providing efficient and effective uptake from the interstitial fluid during capillary exchange.

A5.text: Dietary triglycerides combine with other lipids and proteins, and enter the lacteals to form a milky fluid called chyle.

A6.text: Lymphatic capillaries called lacteals are critical for the transport of dietary lipids and lipid-soluble vitamins to the bloodstream.

A7.text: Its network of capillaries and collecting lymphatic vessels efficiently drain and transport extravasated fluid, along with proteins and antigens, back to the circulatory system.

A8.text: When interstitial fluid increases, it causes swelling that stretches collagen fibers anchored to adjacent connective tissue, opening the unidirectional valves at the ends of these capillaries and facilitating the entry and subsequent drainage of excess lymph fluid.

A9.text: Lymph enters the convex side of a lymph node through multiple afferent lymphatic vessels.

A10.text: The endothelium of the subcapsular sinus is continuous with that of the afferent lymph vessel.
